title: 111_hr6309
content: The Act may be cited as the "Notification of Origin of Telecommunications and Internet Consumer Exchanges Act of 2010" or the "NOTICE Act of 2010". Definitions are provided in Section 2. The Act defines key terms such as "business entity" as any organization established for profit through commerce in the US, "commerce" as defined in the Consumer Product Safety Act, and "consumer" as an individual purchasing goods or services for personal use within the US. The curr_chunk discusses definitions related to customer service communication, telecommunication, and wire communication. These terms are crucial for understanding interactions between consumers and businesses in commerce. The curr_chunk defines "communication by wire" as the transmission of various forms of data through wire, cable, or similar connections, including all services and facilities related to such transmission. Business entities engaged in customer service communications must disclose their physical location as required by SEC. 3. Business entities must disclose their physical location at the beginning of customer service communications, except if all employees are in the US or if the communication is initiated by a consumer to a foreign entity. Business entities are exempt from disclosing their physical location in customer service communications if the communication is initiated by the consumer to a foreign entity or if emergency services are being provided. The Federal Trade Commission may exclude certain business entities or customer service communications from requirements if exceptionally compelling circumstances justify it. Each year, participating business entities must certify compliance with customer service communication requirements. The FTC will promulgate necessary regulations within one year of the Act's enactment. The Federal Trade Commission will issue regulations to implement the Act. The Act's requirements for customer service communications will take effect one year after its enactment. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. Any failure to comply with section 3 will be treated as a violation of FTC regulations on unfair or deceptive acts. The FTC has the power to enforce this Act and its regulations, with penalties for violations. The Act's regulations will be enforced by the Federal Trade Commission, with penalties for non-compliance. The Act does not limit the FTC's authority under other laws.
